Background Synovial chondromatosis is a proliferative disease of the synovium associated with cartilage metaplasia 
that causes localized joint pain and affects its function.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 63‑ year ‑old white woman presented with right hip pain, lasting over 10 years. Pelvic radiog‑
raphy showed right hip osteoarthritis and ipsilateral periacetabular opacities. Computed tomography confirmed 
the diagnosis of hip synovial chondromatosis.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Synovial chondromatosis is a benign, rare condition that affects the synovial joints and is characterized 
by the presence of free cartilaginous bodies within the joint capsule. Although the etiology of synovial chondromato ‑
sis is not established, it is known that synovial membrane metaplasia leads to the formation and proliferation of car ‑
tilaginous nodules. The knee is the most affected joint; however, synovial chondromatosis may occur in the shoulder, 
elbow, or, rarely, the hip. As we can see in this case, diagnosis can be made using radiography.
Keywords  Chondromatosis, Synovial membrane, Radiography, Hip joint, Hip pain
Background
Synovial chondromatosis (SC) is a proliferative disease of 
the synovium and stands as a curious and often misun derstood anomaly. Despite its rarity with a reported inci dence of 1 in 100,000, this condition, characterized by the 
formation of cartilage nodules within the synovial mem brane of joints, can significantly impact joint function 
and quality of life, making accurate diagnosis and appro priate treatment essential [1]. In this article, we present a 
case of unusual SC.Presentation
A 63-year-old white woman presented to the rheuma tology department with a 10-year history of mechanical 
right hip pain, progressively worsening over time, signifi cantly impacting her mobility and diminishing her ability 
to walk. Despite multiple treatment modalities including 
analgesics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and 
rehabilitation exercises, her symptoms persisted. Past 
medical history was notable for controlled hypertension, 
dyslipidemia, and a previous diagnosis of greater tro chanteric pain syndrome, for which she had undergone 
multiple trochanteric bursa steroid injections. Her daily 
medication regimen comprised lisinopril, simvastatin, 
and naproxen (ranging from 500 to 1500  mg daily, on 
demand).
On physical examination, she had pain and restricted 
abduction and internal/external rotations of the right hip. 
No other abnormalities were presented. Pelvic radiogra phy revealed signs consistent with right hip osteoarthri tis, along with periacetabular opacities on the ipsilateral Open Access

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Synovial chondromatosis (SC) is a benign, rare condi tion that manifests between the third and fifth decades of 
life [1]. It affects the synovial joints and is characterized 
by the presence of free cartilaginous bodies within the 
joint capsule. Although the etiology is not established, 
it is known that synovial membrane metaplasia leads to the formation and proliferation of cartilaginous nod ules [1, 2]. The knee is the most affected joint; however, 
CS may occur in the shoulder, elbow, or, rarely, the hip 
[1, 3]. Diagnosis can be made using radiography. CT or 
magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan are indicated 
if diagnosis remains unclear. Management strategies for 
SC vary depending on the extent of joint involvement 
and symptom severity. Surgical intervention, including 
synovectomy and removal of loose bodies, remains the 
mainstay of treatment for symptomatic cases. In cases 
where surgery is not feasible, symptomatic relief can be 
achieved through pharmacological management and 
physical therapy [1, 2, 4, 5]. Of note, malignant trans formation rarely occurs [6]. Close monitoring and longterm follow-up are essential to detect disease recurrence 
and ensure optimal outcomes.
This case underscores the importance of thorough clin ical evaluation and appropriate basic imaging studies in 
elucidating the underlying pathology. By raising aware ness of this condition, clinicians can expedite diagnosis 
and implement timely interventions to alleviate symp toms and improve patients’ quality of life.
Conclusion
The patient exhibited multiple synovial chondromas, a 
condition uncommonly encountered. Synovial chondro matosis, although benign, may cause pain and functional 
disability with potential deterioration of the articular
